noun.description: The thick viscous substance secreted by the mucous membranes of the respiratory passages, especially when produced in excessive or abnormal quantities, e.g., when someone is suffering from a cold.

origin: Middle English fleem, fleume, from Old French fleume, from late Latin phlegma clammy moisture (of the body), from Greek phlegma inflammation, from phlegein to burn. The spelling change in the 16th century was due to association with the Latin and Greek.
